info.title: Enabling hotplugging for network bond members

abstract.para: In some network environments (such as &ha;), you might need to replace a bond member interface with a new one, for example, if a network interface has a fault. However, before you can replace the interface you must configure the networking setup to recognize when a new device is added.

listitem.para: A bonded device is already configured as described in .

section.title: Enabling hotplugging for network bond members

step.para: Check that the bond members are configured with BOOTPROTO=none and STARTMODE=hotplug. This should be the default setting. For example, in /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-eth0:

callout.para: BOOTPROTO=none uses the ethtool options (when provided), but does not set up the link on ifup eth0 because the bond member interface is controlled by the bond device.
STARTMODE=hotplug allows the bond member interface to join the bond automatically when it is available.

step.para: Run the command hwinfo --netcard and make a note of the SysFS BusID for each bond member.
Open the file /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules. For each bond member, change the value of KERNELS to match the SysFS BusID from the previous step. For example:
step.screen:
SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", KERNELS=="0000:00:17.0", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth0"
SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", KERNELS=="0000:00:19.0", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth1"
step.para: This configures the udev rules to match the device by bus ID instead of by MAC address, allowing the bond to detect a new device in the same slot but with a different MAC address.

section.para: When one of the bond member interfaces is removed from the system, the kernel removes it from the bond automatically. When a new card is added to the system, udev uses the bus-based persistent name rule to rename the interface to the name of the bond member, and calls ifup for it. The ifup call automatically joins the new interface into the bond.
At boot time, network.service does not wait for the hotplugged bond members, but for the bond to become ready, which only requires one available bond member.
